subnotes.content: Two studies which were developed in New York City and carried out during the 1960s and 1970s concerning children and families were incorporated into the program known as "State of the Child: New York City I and II." Data was collected that focused upon children's health, involvement in school, and the family and communities in which they lived, with the intent of describing the quality of life of the over 2 million children living in New York City at that time and, particularly, those at risk. Using publicly distributed statistics, this pioneering effort to develop a measurable "State of the Child" included child-rearing, income distribution, and services provided by public and voluntary institutions. The emphasis was placed upon what was termed as "applied social indicators" to answer questions regarding the success of school reading programs, health services, children's safety during that time and in the decade or two prior to the study. Program "monitors" in place attempted to recommend improvements in services through monitoring, particularly the child health stations, public school attendance program, food programs in the public schools, and school bilingual programs.
The State of the Child reports and related memoranda are found on reels 99-100.
